div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Sergeant W. N. Beek.--Was killed in the battle at Malvern Hill, July 1st, 1862, Sergeant W. N. Beek, of Norfolk, Va, in the 22d years of his age.

The deceased was a member of Company H, 6th Va. Reg., and was at the post of duty, with his front to the foeman, cheering his comrades to the charge, when he was struck by four balls, two of which penetrated his breast and one his head.
His death was instantaneous and without pain.

He was amongst the first to respond to the call of his native State, and participated with his company in taking the powder from the magazine at Fort Norfolk on the night of the 19th of April, 1861, and was one of the guard who brought it to Richmond.
His intelligence and ready obedience to orders, and his decisive courage, gained the confidence of his officers, while his gentle and generous disposition drew around him every comrade in arms a friend.

While the writer of this is too sad to indulge in the language of eulogy, it is but just to say that, in the great struggle for the independence of our beloved South in which we are engaged, no braver, manlier, or more upright spirit has been offered up on the altar of our country.

It will be some consolation to those who mourn at the saddened homes of his relatives to know that the last offices of earth were performed by careful hands, and that the comrades who were accessible, with sorrowing hearts, deposited his remains in the Old Cemetery, on 2d street, near this city.
* Comrade.

On Friday, the 27th ult., in the charge upon the breastworks, near Gaine's Mill, Samuel A. Toler, of Company E, (Black Eagle Company from Cumberland,) 18th Virginia regiment, fell mortally wounded by a shot in the breast.
He was the oldest son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Toler, of Cumberland.
He was a good son, and with him are lost some of the brightest hopes of his parents.
He was a good friend and companion, beloved by the whole company, and indeed it may truly be said that he had not an ill-wisher in the world.
Among the many who, on that dread evening, feel like autumn leaves around him, there was no purer, nobler, fresher spirit, no braver heart.
It was in the fiercest charge, in the front rank, that he suddenly reeled, called on a companion's name near by, and fell in the ranks; and thus died this gallant young patriot on the field of glory, before the downy bloom of boyhood had well left his cheek, yet facing man fully his country's enemies, and yielding his life a sacrifice for his country's freedom, lamented of all who knew him. That country is indebted to his memory for all that he endured for her, and for a life thus laid down, which in all respects bade fair to be highly prosperous and happy. J. W. M.

div3.p: --From the service of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company, two Negromen, viz:
Pry, belonging to Walker Washington, of Caroline county: about 5 feet 6 inches in height, dark complexion, and dull in appearance.
Reuben, belonging to Alexander Hutcheson, of Richmond city; about 5 feet 6 or 8 inches in height, dark complexion, good countenance, and quick in his movements.
It is supposed that these Negroes are employed in some of the camps, cooking for the soldiers.

Chas. G. Talcott,
jy 21--6t Sup't R. & D. R. R.

div3.head: Ten Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left my premises on Sunday, the 13th day of July, my boy, William. He is a gingerbread color, about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches high, and 16 years old. No marks recollected.
I have reason to believe he is in some of the camps near Richmond.
I will pay the above reward if delivered to me or put in the jail at Richmond or Henrico.
Joseph C. Burton,
jy 21--3t* Three miles North of Richmond.

div3.p:

Said boy was brought from Essex country six months ago. I will pay the above reward if delivered to me in Richmond.
Theodore Frick,
jy 21--6t* Upper Market.

div3.p: --The above reward, or a proportionate rate for any of them, will be paid for the apprehension of the following slaves and their confinement in jail so that I get them again, or their delivery to me, at Petersburg or Maiden's Adventure, Powhatan county:
Daniel, about 30 years old; black; about 5 feet 5 inches high; no marks recollected.
Charles, about 25 years old; black; about 6 feet high; no marks recollected.
Ned, about 21 years old; black; about 5 feet 8 inches; no marks.
David, about 40 years old; black; about 5 feet 6 inches; no marks.
Ann, about 32 years old; black; about 5 feet 2 inches; no marks.
Eliza, about 14 years old; black.
Matthew, about 25 years old; black; 5 feet 8 inches.

div3.head: Ten Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off from my premises, on Federal street, on 16th inst., my woman Emily.

I will give the above reward for her confinement in some jail, so I can get her again.
One of her eyes was swollen when she left, from cold.
